1.78.text:
The first time I ever played
Glazunov's violin concerto

5.56.text: was actually my first North American engagement of note.

9.22.text:
It was with the Vancouver Symphony
Orchestra and Bramwell Tovey

13.46.text: and I was maybe eighteen, maybe seventeen-eighteen?

18.62.text: I was very young and decided to learn that concerto for that engagement.

24.46.text: Those are the kind of stupid mistakes I made back then.

27.18.text:
Not that I'm completely
incapable of making stupid mistake now,

30.87.text:
but that sort of thing I almost
definitely would not do.

34.79.text: Learn a brand new concerto to play your debut

37.06.text: with an orchestra for the first time in a territory.

40.44.text: I learnt the piece, I always learn things quite quickly and well.

46.20.text: I felt quite good with it.

48.22.text: Then a couple of days before the concert I trapped my--

53.68.text: So I went there like, "okay, this is a challenge and a half."

59.08.text:
I feel a close affinity to, as do you
with any work

63.14.text: that's been key in your first couple of years

66.76.text: of experiencing being out there, performing live

69.10.text: and under all of that pressure.

71.16.text: So I definitely have a very,

73.15.text:
very kind of inextricable connection
with it.

76.39.text:
I think it's a very uplifting concerto, it
has a lot of humor,

80.05.text: it has a lot of playfulness,

84.35.text: the entire-- I mean the concerto is in one sweep

88.16.text:
so you never really stop or have a
break

91.70.text:
and the listener most definitely
doesn't.

94.77.text:
Very rhapsodic, I mean there
are almost too many themes that

99.41.text:
you would imagine to be the one and only
theme.

110.13.text:
incredible use of the registers of the
instrument. You start incredibly low,

114.94.text: most of the melodies are established in the lower register

119.22.text:
and then we have the
satisfaction of the violinist getting to,

124.84.text: to sing the 'opera voice', very, very high.

132.82.text: I mean, if people aren't smiling

136.40.text: you've missed the point I think.
